concept.title: Role-based access for administrators
concept.shortdesc: Authorization defines the roles that Couchbase administrators perform after they connect to the system.

dlentry.dd: The initial built-in full Couchbase administrator authenticated during Couchbase Server installation has the full access and privileges to manage all Couchbase Server functions. There is one full administrator per Couchbase Server, and his user ID is mapped from the LDAP server using the Couchbase Web Console, as explained in Authentication.

Privileges include:
Cluster: write configuration, read configuration, security configuration
Bucket: write configuration, read configuration
Index: manage view index, manage spatial index
XDCR: manage references, manage replication, manage pause resume replication, read configuration
The read-only Couchbase administrator has a restricted read-only access to Couchbase Server functions. The read-only administrator can view certain activities without having the ability to edit.
These administrators are set up using the Couchbase Web Console.

Privileges include:
Cluster: read configuration
Bucket: read configuration
XDCR: read configuration

section.title: New administrative roles
section.p: Several new administrative roles have been introduced to achieve segregation of duties for administrators.

dlentry.dd: Administrators in this role can manage all cluster operations except for the cluster security settings. They are unable to update the Administrator credentials, enable/disable LDAP or modify auditing settings.

Privileges include:
Cluster: write configuration, read configuration
Bucket: write configuration, read configuration
Index: manage view index, manage spatial index
XDCR: manage references, manage replication, manage pause resume replication, read configuration
These are administrators for individual buckets.

Privileges include:
Bucket: write configuration, read configuration
Index: manage view index, manage spatial index
XDCR: manage pause resume replication
Lead application developers must have access to the data to define views and run views on data to ensure the correctness of the views. They also define 2i indexes and spatial views.

Privileges include:
Bucket: read configuration
Index: manage view index, manage spatial index

Remote teams responsible for configuring XDCR topology and managing replications for High Availability previously had to share administrative credentials. Now they can be added to the Replication administration role to manage these tasks.

Privileges include:
XDCR: manage references, manage replication, manage pause resume replication, read configuration
